page.title: 03Ribble Valley, Lancashire
page.content: The village of Whalley and the surrounding district lie in the beautiful valley of the{River Ribble} which rises in the{Yorkshire Dales}and enters the{Irish Sea}at{Preston.} The{Ribble Valley}forms a natural boundary between the large{industrial areas of south Lancashire, including the old cotton towns of{Blackburn, {Bolton,Burnley}and{Accrington,}and the mainly rural area of north Lancashire- the{Trough of Bowland}regarded as the gateway to the{Lake District. { }Most of this vast rural area is intensively farmed -{dairy herds}of {fresian}cows with perhaps sheep, pigs, poultry or beef cattle to supplement income. There is very little arable farming, the land being used for grazing, and grass cutting, for hay or the increasingly more popular silage.
